Colin, I just wanted to second that I believe the GUI stuff is quite 
impor=
tant for the reasons you stated.  They really help you 
understand what's g=
oing on and thereby debug and better optimize 
parameters.

Also, SharpNEAT=
 is one of the fastest versions of NEAT available.  
The regression experim=
ents can run 100,000 generations in a few 
hours, which is impressive.  Wil=
l the same optimizations that allow 
that performance really hold after tra=
nsferring it over?

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Colin Green" <locste=
r01@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Jim,
> 
> On 19/12/2007, Jim O'Flaherty, Jr. <jim_of=
laherty_jr@...> wrote:
> >
> > I am curious as to why you are considering s=
hifting from .NET/C# 
to Java. Given the conversion will cost you developme=
nt time, what 
advantages are you gaining in Java, or disadvantages in movi=
ng away 
from .NET/C#?
> >
> > BTW, I ask this as I have been attempting to=
 evaluate performance 
between these two platforms. To what degree, if at a=
ll, is your move 
performance motivated?
> 
> 
> Actually performance isn't=
 really a major factor in my thinking. The
> Java and .Net compilers and ru=
ntime environments are all well 
thought
> out and fast environments in my =
opinion. OK so you've got different
> Java VM's from different vendors for =
different scenarios, but 
they're
> all good including the standard (free) =
ones. And in the .Net world 
you
> have Mono which was quite slow when I la=
st tried it last (12 months
> ago ish). But generally if you see significan=
t performance 
differences
> it's most likely the code you're using, not th=
e environment. As I 
say
> the generics support in .Net is more performant,=
 so that does tilt 
the
> performance argument slightly in favour of .Net
>=
 
> For me the main argument for Java is the Eclipse IDE. It's far 
easier
=
> to navigate through code using views such as the type and call
> hierarch=
y, highlighting of variables, errors, warnings, TODO 
comments,
> etc. on t=
he right hand margin. The CVS/SVN support is really nice to
> use - Visual =
Studio's equivalents are either very poor by comparison
> (SourceSafe) or v=
ery expensive (TeamSuite). Ultimately the Java 
coding
> experience is nice=
r and makes more efficient use of programmer time
> IMO - a big plus in my =
book.
> 
> So although I prefer the .Net framework, the IDE's let the side =

down.
> Add to that the fact that Java is more open source friendly and th=
at
> could sway the argument for me. Yes you can get a free version of 
VS,=

> but (a) it's not as good as Eclipse (also free) and (b) it has some
> fe=
atures disabled - 64bit support and multithreaded debugging are 
two
> I bu=
mped into recently.
> 
> Development time is an issue. Not so much porting =
the core algorithm
> stuff as I'm intending to refactor all of that anyway,=
 but all the
> graphical stuff and GUI interfaces could be a serious headac=
he.
> 
> Colin.
>
